head.title: Hypothesis Testing for the Population Proportion p

body.p: The purpose of this activity is to give you guided practice exploring the effect of sample size on the significance of sample results, and help you get a better sense of this effect. Another important goal of this activity is to help you understand the distinction between statistical significance and practical importance.
For this activity, we will use example 1. Here is a summary of what we have found:

image.alt: The entire population is represented as a large circle, representing products produced by the machine (following the repair). We are interested in p for this population, which is the proportion of defective products. H_0: p = .20, H_a: p < .20 . From the population we generate a sample of 400 products, and find that 64 are defective. Our conditions are met, and we find that p-hat = 64/400 = .16, z = -2, and p-value = .023 . We conclude that H_0 can be rejected.

body.p: The results of this study—64 defective products out of 400—were statistically significant in the sense that they provided enough evidence to conclude that the repair indeed reduced the proportion of defective products from 0.20 (the proportion prior to the repair). Even though the results—a sample proportion of defective products of 0.16—are statistically significant, it is not clear whether the results indicate that the repair was effective enough to meet the company's needs, or, in other words, whether these results have a practical importance. If the company expected the repair to eliminate defective products almost entirely, then even though statistically, the results indicate a significant reduction in the proportion of defective products, this reduction has very little practical importance, because the repair was not effective in achieving what it was supposed to. To make sure you understand this important distinction between statistical significance and practical importance, we will push this a bit further.
Consider the same example, but suppose that when the company examined the 400 randomly selected products, they found that 78 of them were defective (instead of 64 in the original problem):

image.alt: A large circle represents the entire population of products produced by the machine (following the repair). We want to find p for this population, which is the proportion of defective products. Our two hypotheses are H_0: p=.20, H_a: p<.20. We create a sample of 400 products (represented by a smaller circle). We find that 78 are defective, so p-hat = 78/400 = .195

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: From the background we know that there are n=400, x=78, and the null value is p=0.20. Here are the basic commands:
To calculate z, enter the following command. (Since the sample proportion is less than p = 0.2, we know that z will be negative, so we take the negative square root.)
The provided p-value is equivalent to the p-value we might find from the z-test we hand calculate for proportions.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: Carry out the z-test using StatCrunch (instructions reviewed below)

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Proportions → One sample → with summary
Enter the number of successes and observations
Select Hypothesis Test for p
Enter a null value and choose the form of the alternative hypothesis from the options not equal, less than, and greater than
Choose the form of the alternative hypothesis
Press Compute!

alternative.p: If the raw data are given:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Proportions → One sample → with data
Values in: select column with sample data
Success: specify the value that denotes success.
Perform: select Hypothesis Test for p
Enter a null value and choose the form of the alternative hypothesis from the options not equal, less than, and greater than
Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: Carry out the test using Minitab (instructions are reviewed below).
Minitab instructions review (z-test for the population proportion p):

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Basic Statistics → 1 Proportion

Enter the data:
If you have the raw data in a Minitab worksheet, choose the "Samples in columns" option, and enter the column containing the data.
If the data are summarized, enter the sample size, and how many of the subjects have the characteristic of interest.

Click on "Options"
Next to "Test proportion", enter the null value, po.
Choose the relevant alternative.
Check "Use this....normal distribution."
Click "OK" twice.

body.p: Consider now another variation on the same problem. Assume now that over a period of a month following the repair, the company randomly selected 20,000 products, and found that 3,900 of them were defective.

image.alt: A large circle represents the entire population of products produced by the machine (following the repair). We want to find p for this population, which is the proportion of defective products. Our two hypotheses are H_0: p=.20, H_a: p<.20. We create a sample of 20000 products (represented by a smaller circle). We find that 3900 are defective, so p-hat = 3900/20000 = .195

body.p: Note that the sample proportion of defective products is the same as before , 0.195, which as we established before, does not indicate any practically important reduction in the proportion of defective products.
